description: From Middle English ernest, eornest, from Old English eornest, eornost, eornust (â€œearnestness, zeal, seriousness, battleâ€), from Proto-Germanic *ernustuz (â€œearnest, strength, solidity, struggle, fightâ€), a derivative of Proto-Germanic *arniz (â€œefficient, capable, diligent, sureâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *er- (â€œto cause to move, arouse, increaseâ€). Cognate with West Frisian earnst (â€œearnest, seriousnessâ€), Dutch ernst (â€œseriousness, gravity, earnestâ€), German Ernst (â€œseriousness, earnestness, zeal, vigourâ€), Icelandic ern (â€œbrisk, vigorousâ€), Gothic ğŒ°ğ‚ğŒ½ğŒ¹ğŒ±ğŒ° (arniba, â€œsecure, certain, sureâ€).

The adjective is from Middle English eornest, from Old English eornoste (â€œearnest, zealous, seriousâ€), from the noun. Cognate with North Frisian ernste (â€œearnestâ€), Middle Low German ernest, ernst (â€œserious, earnestâ€), German ernst (â€œserious, earnestâ€).

adjectives.description: earnest (comparative earnester or more earnest, superlative earnestest or most earnest)

entries.meaning: (said of an action or an utterance) Serious or honest.
(with a positive sense) Focused in the pursuit of an objective; eager to obtain or do.
Intent; focused; showing a lot of concentration.
(said of a person or a person's character) Possessing or characterised by seriousness.
Serious; weighty; of a serious, weighty, or important nature; important.

examples: He wrote well in a forcible, colloquial style, with the air of being tremendously in earnest, and full of knowledge which overflowed his pages, tricked out with somewhat boisterous illustrations.

entries.meaning: Seriousness; reality; actuality (as opposed to joking or pretence)

verbs.description: earnest (third-person singular simple present earnests, present participle earnesting, simple past and past participle earnested)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be serious with; use in earnest.
examples: Let's prove among ourselves our armes in jest, That when we come to earnest them with men, We may them better use.

description: Uncertain; apparently related to erres. Compare also arles.

entries.meaning: A sum of money paid in advance as a deposit; hence, a pledge, a guarantee, an indication of something to come.
examples: Now he that hath wrought us for the selfsame thing is God, who also hath given unto us the earnest of the Spirit.

entries.meaning: (archaic) second-person singular simple present form of earn
